To follow and Appease it, but you said you loved me.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I do, if you can wisely entertain it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then you must love my honour,
A Virgins wealth, for every honest Man
Or Woman has an honour, and that has
Engaged my heart already by a Contract;
This tie dissolved with justice, I should kneel
To ask your Princely favour.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am answered.
Who waits? call my Lord Contarini hither.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: You might have mocked another person,
And not have made me a ridiculous story
To your Mistress Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Engage me to mediation for her love,
With a pretence how much my act should honour
Your faint hopes, when you are conscious of a
Contract, already past between you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Contract Sir?
She never yet gave me any language
Did promise hope, she still concluded me
With going to a Cloister.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: How is this fair one?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It is most sure I am contracted.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Vergerio your Lordships Agent.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That boy betray me?
In whom I took delight, made him my friend,
He play the Traitor? I will be revenged upon
His heart.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Contain your passion Contarini,
Her beauty had a power above my friendship,
It well might shake his faith, and yet it is strange.
Call in Vergerio.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have heard all,
And come to meet my sentence. You are a Prince
Against whom I dare not lift a thought; I see
What storm is rising, yet let this, great Sir,
Invite your mercy to me, I have made
No breach against your love, and that which was
My fault to his, may be excused, by what
He felt himself love, not to be resisted.
This Virgin I lay claim to, and her vows
No Subject must compel me to resign;
But if the Prince think me unfit, and call
This treasure from my bosom, and can place
His love, where I so chastely have delighted,
I will not keep a thought that shall repine,
When I am miserable in her absence,
But give my interest cheerfully; to you,
My Lord, I answer, I have made no trespass,
And shall, so please your highness to be Judge,
Make it appear.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Was ever such an impudence?
This presence does protect him, I should else
Write treason on his heart; But Angellina
I pity thy undoing, how canst thou
Expect a truth from him, betrays his Master?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: My Lord, you have been faulty sure, and this
(not worthy to be called a loss of me)
Was meant by Providence to wake your faith,
That is owing to another.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Possible?
The Vice-roy of Sicily's Daughter? Pulcheria.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pulcheria here?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Here Contarini.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ha, proved a Woman, O my shame and folly!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon my too much love, that made me fear
You had forgot Pulcheria, though you left
Your vows and me at Sicily, when you were
Ambassador from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Whence embarked
Thou broughtest me news Pulcheria was drowned,
And thou for her sake entertained my servant,
Welcome, at once receive me and forgive me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I had your promise, were this contract void
In honour, nor will take from my own merit
To think when your considerate thoughts come home,
You can pretend excuse to your own happiness,
Which lest you may suspect, let us in state
Visit Paulina, and unmask that counterfeit
Which hath usurped our name.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir we attend you,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This blessing must require a spacious soul,
Mine is too narrow to receive.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I am not yet created honourable.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Sir, things must have their time, but will his highness
Remove so suddenly, and carry my Lady
To the Court with him? it is a most sweet young Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Order was given to pack up her plate,
Her gold and Jewels, for he means to have
Tiltings and triumphs when he comes to Parma.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: There it is fit we should expect our honours.
I will attend the Prince.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray tell my Lady, I would kiss her hand,
And shall present news will secure their welcome.
I come from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince my Lord?
He is within---

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A small march off the Castle, and commanded
Me to prepare her, that he comes to be
Her guest.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Lord, I will acquaint some of the bed-chamber, but,
When did your Lordship see his Highness?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I left him at the Park gate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is the nearest way unless his highness
Have leaped a window, or can walk invisible.
Your Lordship may have some conceit. I will go Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: What is the meaning that there is such a guard
Upon our Castle? it is besieged, and no man
Suffered go forth; this is some Lord or other
By his straddling.

div2.stage: Enter Lucio, Longino, Strozzo, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: From the Prince? that he?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It is as I tell you Sir, there is a little army,
Surrounds the Castle.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: They have no order from his highness.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: We are betrayed again.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Sir, would you speak with the Prince?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why have you such a thing within the Castle?
Who dares be so much Traitor to usurp
That title? Where is that Puppet, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That is his Secretary.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The rest are Lords and Privy Counsellors.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: We are undone.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: It is he, the very he, I dare not look on him;
O for an impudence worth a Chronicle,
To outface him now, it were a possible thing,
If People would believe---

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I will tell my Lady, they are vanished; hum,
I do not like that face.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Come hither fellow, whom do you serve?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What Prince have you within?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The prince of Darkness.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: a Knight of the Post, the Pestle is too honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where is your Excellent Lady?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have a guess
If things go on, as I suspect, she will be---

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: At her wits end very shortly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An ingenious fellow?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have conversed a little with the Mathematics,
Sir, Who is that Gentlewoman, not that I am ignorant,
But to satisfy a doubt?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: She is one that may be
The Prince of Parma's Lady, when the Priest
Hath done his Office.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: If I be not mistaken
Here comes the Princess, that is Angellina
The younger Sister.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It is my wonder you that have the face
And garb of Gentlemen, should dare to be
So insolent, to affront our person,
And his, to whom your hearts and knees owe reverence.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Command the Impostor forth,
Seize on the Traitors.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His Grace will be here presently, fear not Madam,
I would venture a Neck-breaking at some window,
And be content to crawl away a Cripple;
But there is no hope to scape the Multitude
That will be scrambling for my limbs. Great Sir,
I challenge the privilege of the last Bando,
He that can bring Frapolo the chief Bandit,
Beside what was proclaimed other reward,
Shall have free pardon for all past-offences;
To that Grace I appeal, and here produce
Frapolo.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: This amazeth me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Can you stand
The dazzling Sun so long, and not be struck
Blind for this bold affront? what wildness brought you
In multitudes to fright my happy peace,
And this good Ladies, my most virtuous Consort?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He bears up still!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Have all my cares and watchings to preserve
Your lives, and dearest liberties, deserved
This strange return, and at a time when most
Your happiness is concerned, since by our Marriage
With this sweet Lady, full of grace and beauty,
You may expect an Heir to bless your Country.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Will you suffer him?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: It is time your Prince were dead, and when I am
Companion to my Fathers dust, these tumults
Fomented by seditious men, that are
Weary of Plenty, and delights of Peace,
Shall not approach to interrupt the calm
Good Princes after Death enjoy. Go home,
I pray depart, I rather will submit
To be deposed, than wear a power or title
That shall not all be dedicate to serve you;
My life is but the gift of Heaven, to wast it
For your dear sakes, my People are my Children,
Whom I am bound in Nature and Religion
To cherish and protect. Perhaps you have
Some grievance to present, you shall have justice
Against the proudest here; I look not on
Nobility of Birth, Office, or Fortunes,
The poorest subject has a Native Charter
And a Birth-right to the Laws, and Common wealth,
Which with an equal, and impartial stream,
Shall flow to every bosom.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Pious Prince!

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am at a loss to hear him; sure I am
Farnese, if I be not lost by the way.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Stand off Gentlemen,---let me see---which?
Hum! this---no, the other. Hum! send for a Lion
And turn him loose, he will not hurt the true Prince.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Do not you know me Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, I know you too well, but it stands not
With my honour; what composition?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Who am I? Gentlemen, how dare ye suffer
This thing to talk? if I be your Farnese.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I say I am the Prince,

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Prince of what?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Of Rogues, and please thy Excellence.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You must excuse, I can hold out no longer
These were my Subjects Sir, and if they find
Your Mercy, I am but one, whose head removed,
Or noosed, this Lady will be soon a Widow,
Whom I have not deceived, it was her Ambition
To go no less than Prince, and now you have one,
During this Gentleman's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What scorn shall I become?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Let him be guarded, and all his puppet Lords.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: News, news, excellent news; I shall leap
Out of my flesh for joy. Sir I have undertook
For your pardon to this reverend couple,
They heard my Niece was to be married
To the Prince, and thought it treason to conceal---

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Paulina is not my Niece, no blood of mine;
Where is this Lady and her Pageant Prince?
The truth is, she is not Paulina, but their
Own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Possible? then we are both cheated.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Whom she obtruded on our Family
When our Paulina died an Infant, with her,
A Nurse to both; Does your Grace apprehend?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We do beseech your pardon.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now Angellina thou art heir to all.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: By all this Circumstance you are but my Sister!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The Prince is proved a Prince of Thieves.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why there is a Baggage and a Thief well met then.
I knew she was a Bastard, or a Changeling.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Where shall I hide my shame? O curst Ambition!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give you joy Sir, my most illustrious Nephew,
Joy to thy invisible Grace.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thanks to our loving Uncle:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Take hence the Traitors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sir I beseech a pardon to their lives.
Let nothing of my story be remembered
With such a Tragedy, it is my first Petition.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I must not deny thee; all thank her Virtue;
Live you, and love that Gentlewoman; But
It were a sin to innocence, and our honour
Would encourage Treason by example,
If they should scape all Justice, take them to Custody:
Frapalo, we confine you to this Castle,
Where If she please your Bride may accompany you
Till we determine otherwise.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is some mercy; but
I shall be getting Children, and two nothings
Will not maintain a Family, it were as good
To hang me out of the way, ere Charge come on,
Or take away my tools, I shall be working.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Provision shall be made you shall not starve
Nor surfeit Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Because I called her Sister,
I will contribute something to their fortune.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What thy own goodness will direct; and now
Remove the Scene to Court, to perfect there
My own, and Parma's happiness; pride has
Met with severe reward, and that high justice
(That Governs all) though envy break with her
Own Poison, calls the Amazed World to see
What blessings wait upon Humility.

sp.speaker: Frapolo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, do not say you see me; I have made an escape from the Prince and Paulina; his graces word is but mortal, and not security enough for me; for all this Sun-shine he may hang me, when I come to Parma, for an example, and therefore I have chosen, rather to trust to my legs, than a reconciled State-Enemy.
sp.l: It would not be worth your glory to betray
A man distressed, whom your own mercy may
Preserve to better service; rather than
Go back I will stand your Justice Gentlemen.
I have played the thief, but you, as the case stands,
May save or kill, my life is now in your hands.
